sen.j: 丹波道主王命（たんばのみちのうしのみこと、生没年不詳）とは、記紀における皇族（王族）。
sen.e: Tanbanomichinoushi no mikoto (丹波道主王:year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicle of Japan).
sen.cmt: 名前漢字表記を加えました。 記紀→統一用語では the Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicle of Japan)とするよう指示がありましたが、書物名初出なので、他の書物同様に"Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicle of Japan)としました
sen.e: Tanbanomichinoushi no mikoto (丹波道主王:year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: Chronicle をChroniclesと複数形に変更
sen.e: Tanbanomichinoushi no mikoto (丹波道主王:year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who appears in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 『日本書紀』では丹波道主王、丹波道主命、『古事記』では旦波比古多多須美知能宇斯王。
sen.e: According to the Nihonshoki, his name was written as 丹波道主王 and 丹波道主命, while in "Kojiki," he was refer to as Tanbanohiko tatasumichinoushinoo (旦波比古多多須美知能宇斯王).
sen.cmt: 名前漢字表記を加えました。 旦波比古多多須美知能宇斯王Tanbanohiko tatasumichinoushinoo
sen.e: According to the Nihonshoki, his name was written as 丹波道主王 and 丹波道主命, while in Kojiki, he was refer to as Tanbanohiko tatasumichinoushinoo (旦波比古多多須美知能宇斯王).
According to the Nihonshoki, his name was written as 丹波道主王 and 丹波道主命, while in Kojiki, he was refer to as Tanbanohiko tatasumichinoushinoo (旦波比古多多須美知能宇斯王).

sen.j: 四道将軍のひとりで、丹波に派遣されたとされる。
sen.e: He was said to be one of the Shido-shogun (Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits), and he was dispatched to Tanba Province.
He was said to be one of the Shido-shogun (Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits), and he was dispatched to Tanba Province.
He was said to be one of the Shido-shogun (Generals Dispatched to Four Circuits), and he was dispatched to Tanba Province.
He was the grandfather of Emperor Keiko by his mother.
He was the maternal grandfather of Emperor Keiko.
sen.cmt: 外祖父をmaternal grandfatherと訳出し（出典は京都プロジェクト用語集）
sen.e: He was the maternal grandfather of Emperor Keiko.

sen.j: 彦坐王（ひこいますのみこ）の子で、開化天皇の孫に当たる。
sen.e: He was the son of Hikoimasu no miko and the grandson of Emperor Kaika.
He was a son of Hikoimasu no miko and a grandson of Emperor Kaika.
He was a son of Hikoimasu no miko and a grandson of Emperor Kaika.

sen.j: 母は息長水依比売娘（おきながのみずよりひめ。天之御影神の女）。
sen.e: His mother was Okinaga no mizuyori hime.She was the daughter of Amenomikage no kami.
His mother was Okinaga no mizuyori hime (She was the daughter of Amenomikage no kami).
sen.cmt: 「の女」では意味をなさないので、Webを参照して「天之御影神」を補足しました。
sen.e: His mother was Okinaga no mizuyori hime (She was the daughter of Amenomikage no kami).

sen.j: 同母兄弟に、水穂之真若王（近淡海安直の祖）、神大根王（本巣国造・三野前国造の祖）、水穂五百依比売、御井津比売がいる。
sen.e: His brothers by the same mother were Mizuho no mawaka no miko (the ancestor of Chikatsuomi kanunowake), Kanunoone no miko (the ancestor of Motosunokuni miyatsuko and Minonosakinokuni no miyatsuko), Mizuho no ihoyorihime, Miitsuhime.

His brothers by the same mother were Mizuho no mawaka no miko (the ancestor of Chikatsuomi kanunowake), Kanunoone no miko (the ancestor of Motosunokuni miyatsuko and Minonosakinokuni no miyatsuko), Mizuho no ihoyorihime, Miitsuhime.

His brothers by the same mother were Mizuho no mawaka no miko (the ancestor of Chikatsuomi kanunowake), Kanunoone no miko (the ancestor of Motosunokuni miyatsuko and Minonosakinokuni no miyatsuko), Mizuho no ihoyorihime, Miitsuhime.

sen.j: 一説に彦湯産隅命（ひこゆむすみのみこと、開化天皇の子）の子。
sen.e: According to a theory, he was the son of Hikoyumusumi no mikoto (Emperor Kaika's son).
According to a theory, he was a son of Hikoyumusumi no mikoto (Emperor Kaika's son).
According to a theory, he was a son of Hikoyumusumi no mikoto (Emperor Kaika's son).

sen.j: 妻は、丹波之河上之摩須郎女（たんばのかわかみのますのいらつめ）。
sen.e: His wife was Tanbanokawakami no masu no iratsume.
His wife was Tanbanokawakami no masu no iratsume.
His wife was Tanbanokawakami no masu no iratsume.

sen.j: 子は日葉酢媛命（垂仁天皇皇后）、渟葉田瓊入媛（同妃）、真砥野媛（同妃）、薊瓊入媛（同妃）、竹野媛、朝廷別王(三川穂別の祖）。
sen.e: His children were Hibasu hime (Empress of Emperor Suinin), Nuhatanoniiri hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Matono hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Azaminiiri hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Takano hime, Mikadowakenoo (ancestor of Mikawano honowake).

His children were Hibasu hime (Empress of Emperor Suinin), Nuhatanoniiri hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Matono hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Azaminiiri hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Takano hime, Mikadowakenoo (ancestor of Mikawano honowake).

His children were Hibasu hime (Empress of Emperor Suinin), Nuhatanoniiri hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Matono hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Azaminiiri hime (consort of Emperor Suinin), Takano hime, Mikadowakenoo (ancestor of Mikawano honowake).

sen.j: 記には他に歌凝比売命。
sen.e: According to the Kojiki, Utagorihime no mikoto was also his daughter.
According to the Kojiki, Utagorihime no mikoto was also his daughter.
According to the Kojiki, Utagorihime no mikoto was also his daughter.

sen.j: 京都府久美浜の地名は、道主命の伺帯した「国剣」から「国見」「久美」となり「くみのみなと」「くみの見谷」「くみの浜」など久美浜の地名の起源になったと言われる。
sen.e: The origin of the name Kumihama in Kyoto Prefecture is 'kunitsurugi' (国剣) that Michinoushi no mikoto carried, but later it was changed to 'Kunimi,' 'Kumi,' and then forming the name 'Kumi no minato' (Kumi port), 'Kumi no miya' (valley with the view of Kumi), 'Kumi no hama' (Kumi Beach), etc.
sen.cmt: 「国剣」→正式な読み方が不明です：'kunitsurugi' (国剣)としました。 「くみのみなと」'→Kumi no minato' (Kumi port) と（）内を加えました。 「くみの見谷」→'Kumi no miya' (valley with the view of Kumi) と（）内を加えました。 「くみの浜」→'Kumi no hama' (Kumi Beach)と（）内を加えました。
sen.e: The name of the place Kumihama in Kyoto Prefecture was first 'kunitsurugi' (国剣), a sword being carried by Michinoushi no mikoto, and later it changed to 'Kunimi,' 'Kumi,' forming names such as 'Kumi no minato' (Kumi port), 'Kumi no miya' (valley with the view of Kumi), and 'Kumi no hama' (Kumi Beach), which were thought to be the origin of the name Kumihama.

The name of the place Kumihama in Kyoto Prefecture was first 'kunitsurugi' (国剣), a sword being carried by Michinoushi no mikoto, and later it changed to 'Kunimi,' 'Kumi,' forming names such as 'Kumi no minato' (Kumi port), 'Kumi no miya' (valley with the view of Kumi), and 'Kumi no hama' (Kumi Beach), which were thought to be the origin of the name Kumihama.
